The Act is titled the "Christopher Reeve Paralysis Act" and includes sections on paralysis research, rehabilitation research and care, and improving quality of life for persons with paralysis and other physical disabilities. Sec. 301 of the Christopher Reeve Paralysis Act focuses on programs to enhance the quality of life for individuals with paralysis and other physical disabilities. This is part of the coordination of paralysis research and programs outlined in the Act. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may expand and coordinate research on paralysis, collaborating with other agencies to avoid duplication of activities. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may award grants for paralysis research consortia to conduct basic and clinical research activities. A report to Congress on paralysis activities and future strategies is also required by December 1, 2003. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may award grants for paralysis research consortia to conduct basic and clinical research activities, focus on advancing treatments and developing therapies, and facilitate the dissemination of clinical and scientific findings. Coordination of information among consortia and regular communication between members are also required, along with periodic reports on activities. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may award grants for paralysis research consortia to conduct basic and clinical research activities, focus on advancing treatments and developing therapies, and facilitate the dissemination of clinical and scientific findings. Each consortium may use the facilities of a single lead institution or be formed from several cooperating institutions. The Director may provide a mechanism for public input on existing and planned programs and research activities, and there are authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Additional appropriations may be necessary for fiscal years 2003 through 2006, in addition to any other amounts appropriated for the same purpose. TITLE II-- PARALYSIS REHABILITATION RESEARCH AND CARE

SEC. 201. Expansion and coordination of activities of National Institutes of Health for research enhancing daily function for persons with paralysis. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may expand and coordinate research activities for people with paralysis. This includes collaboration with other agencies and the establishment of Paralysis Clinical Trials Networks. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may award grants to establish multicenter networks for clinical trials on paralysis resulting from CNS trauma, disorders, or stroke. These networks will focus on designing rehabilitation intervention protocols and outcome measures. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may award grants to establish multicenter networks for clinical trials on paralysis resulting from CNS trauma, disorders, or stroke. These networks will focus on promoting behavioral adaptation to functional losses, assessing the efficacy of medical rehabilitation therapies, developing improved assistive technology, understanding whole body system responses to physical impairments, disabilities, and limitations, and replicating findings for scientific and translation purposes. The Director may coordinate clinical trials networks, ensuring information sharing and regular communication among members. A report on research activities enhancing daily function for persons with paralysis must be submitted by December 1, 2003. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Title III focuses on improving the quality of life for individuals with paralysis and other physical disabilities through various programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may study health challenges related to paralysis and physical disabilities, develop a national action plan, and implement projects to enhance the quality of life for individuals with these conditions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may study health challenges related to paralysis and physical disabilities, develop a national action plan, and implement projects to enhance the quality of life for individuals with these conditions. This includes support for disseminating information on care and rehabilitation options, establishing a hospital-based paralysis registry, and developing innovative programs and services through the Comprehensive Paralysis and Other Physical Disability Quality of Life Program. The Secretary may award grants to nonprofit organizations for innovative programs supporting individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities, focusing on caregiver education, physical activity, prevention of complications, home-based interventions, education for healthcare providers, community integration, and underserved populations. The Secretary may award grants to nonprofit organizations for innovative programs supporting individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities, focusing on caregiver education, physical activity, prevention of complications, home-based interventions, education for healthcare providers, community integration, and underserved populations. Health and disability organizations coordinate services, disseminate information, improve access to services, and test intervention programs to enhance health and quality of life. Activities are coordinated with other Public Health Service agencies, and a report on evaluation results and strategies is submitted to Congress by December 1, 2003. Authorization of appropriations is provided for implementation. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out innovative programs supporting individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. Such sums as necessary are authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. TITLE IV--COORDINATION OF PARALYSIS RESEARCH AND PROGRAMS

SEC. 401. COORDINATION. Establishment of a working group by the Secretary to coordinate paralysis research, public health, and rehabilitation training at the Federal level. The group may include representatives from various organizations such as the National Institutes of Health, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Department of Veterans Affairs, and Department of Defense. The working group established by the Secretary coordinates paralysis research, public health, and rehabilitation training at the Federal level. It includes representatives from organizations like the Department of Defense, Department of Labor, National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research, Social Security Administration, and private entities. The group may submit an annual report on successful and emerging opportunities in paralysis research, education, training, quality of life, or surveillance efforts. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2003 through 2006.
